meanings.def: to tie somebody/something with rope, string, etc. so that they/it cannot move or are held together strongly
examples: bind somebody/something to something She was bound to a chair.
bind somebody/something together They bound his hands together.
bind somebody/something He was left bound and gagged (= tied up and with a piece of cloth tied over his mouth).
The sails are bound to the mast with cord.
She found herself bound hand and foot.

meanings.def: to tie a long thin piece of cloth around something
to make people, organizations, etc. feel united so that they live or work together more happily or effectively
examples: bind A (and B) (together) Organizations such as schools and clubs bind a community together.
bind A to B She thought that having his child would bind him to her forever.

meanings.def: to force somebody to do something by making them promise to do it or by making it their duty to do it
examples: bind somebody (to something) He had been bound to secrecy (= made to promise not to tell people about something).
bind somebody to do something The agreement binds her to repay the debt within six months.

meanings.def: to stick together or to make things stick together in a solid mass
examples: bind (together) Add an egg yolk to make the mixture bind.
bind something (together) Add an egg yolk to bind the mixture together.

meanings.def: to fasten the pages of a book together and put them inside a cover
to sew a piece of material to the edge of something to decorate it or to make it stronger
examples: The blankets were bound with satin.

meanings.def: to tie somebody’s hands and feet together so that they cannot move or escape
to prevent somebody from doing what they want by creating rules, limits, etc.

idioms.def: to tie somebody’s hands and feet together so that they cannot move or escape

meanings.def: an annoying situation that is often difficult to avoid
in a difficult situation that you do not know how to get out of
